snippet: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy who died trying to leap from one rooftop to another highlights how the city landscape can be an attractive, dangerous playground for youths.
abstract: Death of 15-year-old Tyreek Riley of Brooklyn, who suffered a fatal fall trying to leap from roof of four-story building to adjacent rooftop in his Crown Heights neighborhood, underscores risk to young daredevils testing New York's perilous urban landscape.

byline.original: By KIRK SEMPLE and JOHN SURICO
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Al Baker, Winnie Hu, Nate Schweber and Rebecca White, and research by Jack Begg.

lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy who died trying to leap from one rooftop to another highlights how the city landscape can be an attractive, dangerous playground for youths.

headline.main: On Rooftops and Trains, Daredevil Stunts in New York Can Turn Deadly
headline.print_headline: On Subway Trains and Rooftops, City Can Be a Perilous Playground
